review.title: Modeling meaning: computational interpreting and understanding of natural language fragments
review.abstract: In this introductory article we present the basics of an approach to implementing computational interpreting of natural language aiming to model the meanings of words and phrases. Unlike other approaches, we attempt to define the meanings of text fragments in a composable and computer interpretable way. We discuss models and ideas for detecting different types of semantic incomprehension and choosing the interpretation that makes most sense in a given context. Knowledge representation is designed for handling context-sensitive and uncertain / imprecise knowledge, and for easy accommodation of new information. It stores quantitative information capturing the essence of the concepts, because it is crucial for working with natural language understanding and reasoning. Still, the representation is general enough to allow for new knowledge to be learned, and even generated by the system. The article concludes by discussing some reasoning-related topics: possible approaches to generation of new abstract concepts, and describing situations and concepts in words (e.g. for specifying interpretation difficulties).

metadata.title: Modeling of the meaning: computational interpreting and understanding of natural language fragments

sections.text: Unlike other approaches, we try to define the meaning of text fragments in a compositional and computer-interpretable way. We discuss models and ideas for recognizing different kinds of semantic incomprehension and for selecting the interpretation that makes the most sense in a given context. Knowledge presentation is designed for dealing with context-sensitive and uncertain / inaccurate knowledge, as well as for simply ingesting new information. It stores quantitative information that captures the essence of concepts because it is crucial for working with understanding and arguing natural language. Nevertheless, the presentation is generic enough to learn new knowledge and even be generated by the system. The article concludes by discussing some argument-related topics: possible approaches to generating new abstract concepts and describing situations and concepts in words (e.g. specifying interpretation difficulties).

sections.heading: 3 Approach overview
sections.text: The approach is based on blurred logic, as it is a very good tool for working with different levels of truthfulness and concepts with unclear boundaries, phenomena that often occur in knowledge from natural language, and common sense in particular [10]. All knowledge is encoded in blurred properties (with values from zero to one), each of which encodes an independent piece of information. Contexts and context hierarchies are used to structure knowledge and model its context sensitivity. Context is defined as a coordinate system: If N is the number of independent properties in a given context, it means that the context contains N axes, and knowledge in that context is described as a blurred region in a N-dimensional unity. We model phrases, words, and other fragments of natural language as a region that we call meaning operators.

sections.heading: 6 Interpreting phrases

sections.heading: 6.1 Process
sections.text: Let us now briefly discuss the phrase interpretation process. When a new phrase comes into play, we can do the following: First, as far as possible, the syntactic structure of the phrase is obtained from the grammatical forms of the words. In practice, this means determining the sequence of use of operators and block operators to each other. In the case that this structure is ambiguous, we must remember the possible options so that we can compare them later on based on their intelligibility (6,3), and select the best option. Afterwards, we must exert sequential use of operators on each other. More specifically, the operators that modify the internal context of another operator do so (which results in a block operator), while the operators that work only with the external context of the narrative (e.g. phrase context) form a line, in the order of application. The result is phrase operator: composition of multiple block operators that are later applied to the narrative context by the operators.

sections.heading: 6.2 Polysemy and homonyms
sections.text: In the case of homonyms (when words are used in very different contexts), the correct meaning can be recognized almost immediately by comparing the axes of the internal context of the word with the axes of the current context. In the case of similar meanings, the internal contexts of the words will be quite similar. Then, we must take all possible meaning operators for the word and "test" them as part of the phrase operator, selecting the one that best satisfies the comprehension criteria. It would be best if we normally store such similar meanings as a "fuzzier" operator instead of storing separate meanings as separate operators, otherwise there is a risk that too many variants of the phrase meaning will arise (if the phrase contains several such words with polysemy involved).

sections.text: In this section, we will describe some techniques and ideas used to determine whether a statement or phrase makes sense, and choose which of the possible interpretations makes the most of it. sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We have described our approach to working with semantic information, which allows us to define the meaning of words and phrases and formulate criteria for the intelligibility of texts. This possibility potentially enables our system to learn new words using texts intended for people (dictionaries, encyclopaedias, etc.) as long as a certain minimum vocabulary is available. By using the same types of sources, learning can then be verified. For example, if a newly learned word has a known synonym, we can verify the proximity of the corresponding meaning operators. Similarly, meaning operators can be verified, which can be derived from the definitions given in different dictioners.A separate advantage of the method is the ability to express a situation or concept known to the system in words. It can enable a more productive dialogue with a user, and a fuller awareness of the difficulties that the system presents is tangible.

sections.heading: 9 Summary
sections.text: In this introductory article, we have tried to take some modest steps in this area and describe our approach and ideas. Obviously, a lot of research and experimentation needs to be done before it is possible to evaluate any results. However, we would like to emphasize that the approach described in this article has certain advantages over the known and widespread ones. Semantic net-like representations can relatively easily absorb new knowledge, but the relationships between words contain very little quantitative information. Other systems, such as those based on different logical formalities, encode information in detail, but require human work to enter and edit rules, and do not really treat uncertainty and inaccuracy well. None of the presentations attempts to model the concepts for "what they are," and do not capture their essence in quantitative form. This limits the capabilities of these approaches when it comes to complex understanding and related tasks (such as participating in a dialogue).
